You see me here, you gods, a poor old man,
As full of grief as age; wretched in both.
If it be you that stirs these daughters' hearts
Against their father, fool me not so much
To bear it tamely; touch me with noble anger,
And let not women's weapons, water drops,
Stain my man's cheeks! No, you unnatural hags!
I will have such revenges on you both
That all the world shall- I will do such things-
What they are yet, I know not; but they shall be
The terrors of the earth! You think I'll weep.
No, I'll not weep.
I have full cause of weeping, but this heart
Shall break into a hundred thousand flaws
Or ere I'll weep. O fool, I shall go mad!
Exeunt Lear, Gloucester, Kent, and Fool. Storm and tempest.

blocks.speaker: dukecornwall
lines: Let us withdraw; 'twill be a storm.

blocks.speaker: regan
lines: This house is little; the old man and 's people
Cannot be well bestow'd.

blocks.speaker: goneril
lines: 'Tis his own blame; hath put himself from rest
And must needs taste his folly.

blocks.speaker: regan
lines: For his particular, I'll receive him gladly,
But not one follower.

blocks.speaker: goneril
lines: So am I purpos'd.
Where is my Lord of Gloucester?

blocks.speaker: dukecornwall
lines: Followed the old man forth.
[Enter Gloucester.]
He is return'd.

blocks.speaker: glouchester
lines: The King is in high rage.

blocks.speaker: dukecornwall
lines: Whither is he going?

blocks.speaker: glouchester
lines: He calls to horse, but will I know not whither.

blocks.speaker: dukecornwall
lines: 'Tis best to give him way; he leads himself.

blocks.speaker: goneril
lines: My lord, entreat him by no means to stay.

blocks.speaker: glouchester
lines: Alack, the night comes on, and the bleak winds
Do sorely ruffle. For many miles about
There's scarce a bush.

blocks.speaker: regan
lines: O, sir, to wilful men
The injuries that they themselves procure
Must be their schoolmasters. Shut up your doors.
He is attended with a desperate train,
And what they may incense him to, being apt
To have his ear abus'd, wisdom bids fear.

blocks.speaker: dukecornwall
lines: Shut up your doors, my lord: 'tis a wild night.
My Regan counsels well. Come out o' th' storm. [Exeunt.]
Enter Kent and a Gentleman at several doors.

blocks.speaker: earlkent
lines: Who's there, besides foul weather?

blocks.speaker: gentleman-kl
lines: One minded like the weather, most unquietly.

blocks.speaker: earlkent
lines: I know you. Where's the King?

blocks.speaker: gentleman-kl
lines: Contending with the fretful elements;
Bids the wind blow the earth into the sea,
Or swell the curled waters 'bove the main,
That things might change or cease; tears his white hair,
Which the impetuous blasts, with eyeless rage,
Catch in their fury and make nothing of;
Strives in his little world of man to outscorn
The to-and-fro-conflicting wind and rain.
This night, wherein the cub-drawn bear would couch,
The lion and the belly-pinched wolf
Keep their fur dry, unbonneted he runs,
And bids what will take all.

blocks.speaker: earlkent
lines: But who is with him?

blocks.speaker: gentleman-kl
lines: None but the fool, who labours to outjest
His heart-struck injuries.

blocks.speaker: earlkent
lines: Sir, I do know you,
And dare upon the warrant of my note
Commend a dear thing to you. There is division
(Although as yet the face of it be cover'd
With mutual cunning) 'twixt Albany and Cornwall;
Who have (as who have not, that their great stars
Thron'd and set high?) servants, who seem no less,
Which are to France the spies and speculations
Intelligent of our state. What hath been seen,
Either in snuffs and packings of the Dukes,
Or the hard rein which both of them have borne
Against the old kind King, or something deeper,
Whereof, perchance, these are but furnishings-
But, true it is, from France there comes a power
Into this scattered kingdom, who already,
Wise in our negligence, have secret feet
In some of our best ports and are at point
To show their open banner. Now to you:
If on my credit you dare build so far
To make your speed to Dover, you shall find
Some that will thank you, making just report
Of how unnatural and bemadding sorrow
The King hath cause to plain.
I am a gentleman of blood and breeding,
And from some knowledge and assurance offer
This office to you.

blocks.speaker: gentleman-kl
lines: I will talk further with you.

blocks.speaker: earlkent
lines: No, do not.
For confirmation that I am much more
Than my out-wall, open this purse and take
What it contains. If you shall see Cordelia
(As fear not but you shall), show her this ring,
And she will tell you who your fellow is
That yet you do not know. Fie on this storm!
I will go seek the King.

blocks.speaker: gentleman-kl
lines: Give me your hand. Have you no more to say?

blocks.speaker: earlkent
lines: Few words, but, to effect, more than all yet:
That, when we have found the King (in which your pain
That way, I'll this), he that first lights on him
Holla the other.
Exeunt [severally].

scenes.title: Another part of the heath. Storm still.

lines: Enter Lear and Fool.

blocks.speaker: lear
lines: Blow, winds, and crack your cheeks! rage! blow!
You cataracts and hurricanoes, spout
Till you have drench'd our steeples, drown'd the cocks!
You sulph'rous and thought-executing fires,
Vaunt-couriers to oak-cleaving thunderbolts,
Singe my white head! And thou, all-shaking thunder,
Strike flat the thick rotundity o' th' world,
Crack Nature's moulds, all germains spill at once,
That makes ingrateful man!

blocks.speaker: fool-kl
lines: O nuncle, court holy water in a dry house is better than this
rain water out o' door. Good nuncle, in, and ask thy daughters
blessing! Here's a night pities nether wise men nor fools.

blocks.speaker: lear
lines: Rumble thy bellyful! Spit, fire! spout, rain!
Nor rain, wind, thunder, fire are my daughters.
I tax not you, you elements, with unkindness.
I never gave you kingdom, call'd you children,
You owe me no subscription. Then let fall
Your horrible pleasure. Here I stand your slave,
A poor, infirm, weak, and despis'd old man.
But yet I call you servile ministers,
That will with two pernicious daughters join
Your high-engender'd battles 'gainst a head
So old and white as this! O! O! 'tis foul!

blocks.speaker: fool-kl
lines: He that has a house to put 's head in has a good head-piece.
The codpiece that will house
Before the head has any,
The head and he shall louse:
So beggars marry many.
The man that makes his toe
What he his heart should make
Shall of a corn cry woe,
And turn his sleep to wake.
For there was never yet fair woman but she made mouths in a
glass.
Enter Kent.

blocks.speaker: lear
lines: No, I will be the pattern of all patience;
I will say nothing.

blocks.speaker: earlkent
lines: Who's there?

blocks.speaker: fool-kl
lines: Marry, here's grace and a codpiece; that's a wise man and a
fool.

blocks.speaker: earlkent
lines: Alas, sir, are you here? Things that love night
Love not such nights as these. The wrathful skies
Gallow the very wanderers of the dark
And make them keep their caves. Since I was man,
Such sheets of fire, such bursts of horrid thunder,
Such groans of roaring wind and rain, I never
Remember to have heard. Man's nature cannot carry
Th' affliction nor the fear.

blocks.speaker: lear
lines: Let the great gods,
That keep this dreadful pudder o'er our heads,
Find out their enemies now. Tremble, thou wretch,
That hast within thee undivulged crimes
Unwhipp'd of justice. Hide thee, thou bloody hand;
Thou perjur'd, and thou simular man of virtue
That art incestuous. Caitiff, in pieces shake
That under covert and convenient seeming
Hast practis'd on man's life. Close pent-up guilts,
Rive your concealing continents, and cry
These dreadful summoners grace. I am a man
More sinn'd against than sinning.

blocks.speaker: earlkent
lines: Alack, bareheaded?
Gracious my lord, hard by here is a hovel;
Some friendship will it lend you 'gainst the tempest.
Repose you there, whilst I to this hard house
(More harder than the stones whereof 'tis rais'd,
Which even but now, demanding after you,
Denied me to come in) return, and force
Their scanted courtesy.

blocks.speaker: lear
lines: My wits begin to turn.
Come on, my boy. How dost, my boy? Art cold?
I am cold myself. Where is this straw, my fellow?
The art of our necessities is strange,
That can make vile things precious. Come, your hovel.
Poor fool and knave, I have one part in my heart
That's sorry yet for thee.

blocks.speaker: fool-kl
lines: [sings]
He that has and a little tiny wit-
With hey, ho, the wind and the rain-
Must make content with his fortunes fit,
For the rain it raineth every day.

blocks.speaker: lear
lines: True, my good boy. Come, bring us to this hovel.
Exeunt [Lear and Kent].

blocks.speaker: fool-kl
lines: This is a brave night to cool a courtesan. I'll speak a
prophecy ere I go:
When priests are more in word than matter;
When brewers mar their malt with water;
When nobles are their tailors' tutors,
No heretics burn'd, but wenches' suitors;
When every case in law is right,
No squire in debt nor no poor knight;
When slanders do not live in tongues,
Nor cutpurses come not to throngs;
When usurers tell their gold i' th' field,
And bawds and whores do churches build:
Then shall the realm of Albion
Come to great confusion.
Then comes the time, who lives to see't,
That going shall be us'd with feet.
This prophecy Merlin shall make, for I live before his time. Exit.
Enter Gloucester and Edmund.

blocks.speaker: glouchester
lines: Alack, alack, Edmund, I like not this unnatural dealing! When
I desir'd their leave that I might pity him, they took from me
the use of mine own house, charg'd me on pain of perpetual
displeasure neither to speak of him, entreat for him, nor any
way sustain him.

blocks.speaker: edmund
lines: Most savage and unnatural!

blocks.speaker: glouchester
lines: Go to; say you nothing. There is division betwixt the Dukes,
and a worse matter than that. I have received a letter this
night- 'tis dangerous to be spoken- I have lock'd the letter in
my closet. These injuries the King now bears will be revenged
home; there's part of a power already footed; we must incline to
the King. I will seek him and privily relieve him. Go you and
maintain talk with the Duke, that my charity be not of him
perceived. If he ask for me, I am ill and gone to bed. Though I
die for't, as no less is threat'ned me, the King my old master
must be relieved. There is some strange thing toward, Edmund.
Pray you be careful.               Exit.

blocks.speaker: edmund
lines: This courtesy, forbid thee, shall the Duke
Instantly know, and of that letter too.
This seems a fair deserving, and must draw me
That which my father loses- no less than all.
The younger rises when the old doth fall. Exit.

scenes.title: The heath. Before a hovel. Storm still.

lines: Enter Lear, Kent, and Fool.

blocks.speaker: earlkent
lines: Here is the place, my lord. Good my lord, enter.
The tyranny of the open night 's too rough
For nature to endure.

blocks.speaker: lear
lines: Let me alone.

blocks.speaker: earlkent
lines: Good my lord, enter here.

blocks.speaker: lear
lines: Wilt break my heart?

blocks.speaker: earlkent
lines: I had rather break mine own. Good my lord, enter.

blocks.speaker: lear
lines: Thou think'st 'tis much that this contentious storm
Invades us to the skin. So 'tis to thee;
But where the greater malady is fix'd,
The lesser is scarce felt. Thou'dst shun a bear;
But if thy flight lay toward the raging sea,
Thou'dst meet the bear i' th' mouth. When the mind's free,
The body's delicate. The tempest in my mind
Doth from my senses take all feeling else
Save what beats there. Filial ingratitude!
Is it not as this mouth should tear this hand
For lifting food to't? But I will punish home!
No, I will weep no more. In such a night
To shut me out! Pour on; I will endure.
In such a night as this! O Regan, Goneril!
Your old kind father, whose frank heart gave all!
O, that way madness lies; let me shun that!
No more of that.

blocks.speaker: earlkent
lines: Good my lord, enter here.

blocks.speaker: lear
lines: Prithee go in thyself; seek thine own ease.
This tempest will not give me leave to ponder
On things would hurt me more. But I'll go in.
[To the Fool] In, boy; go first.- You houseless poverty-
Nay, get thee in. I'll pray, and then I'll sleep. [Exit Fool]
Poor naked wretches, wheresoe'er you are,
That bide the pelting of this pitiless storm,
How shall your houseless heads and unfed sides,
Your loop'd and window'd raggedness, defend you
From seasons such as these? O, I have ta'en
Too little care of this! Take physic, pomp;
Expose thyself to feel what wretches feel,
That thou mayst shake the superflux to them
And show the heavens more just.

blocks.speaker: edgar
lines: [within] Fathom and half, fathom and half! Poor Tom!
Enter Fool [from the hovel].

blocks.speaker: fool-kl
lines: Come not in here, nuncle, here's a spirit. Help me, help me!

blocks.speaker: earlkent
lines: Give me thy hand. Who's there?

blocks.speaker: fool-kl
lines: A spirit, a spirit! He says his name's poor Tom.

blocks.speaker: earlkent
lines: What art thou that dost grumble there i' th' straw?
Come forth.
Enter Edgar [disguised as a madman].

blocks.speaker: edgar
lines: Away! the foul fiend follows me! Through the sharp hawthorn
blows the cold wind. Humh! go to thy cold bed, and warm thee.

blocks.speaker: lear
lines: Hast thou given all to thy two daughters, and art thou come
to this?

blocks.speaker: edgar
lines: Who gives anything to poor Tom? whom the foul fiend hath led
through fire and through flame, through ford and whirlpool, o'er
bog and quagmire; that hath laid knives under his pillow and
halters in his pew, set ratsbane by his porridge, made him proud
of heart, to ride on a bay trotting horse over four-inch'd
bridges, to course his own shadow for a traitor. Bless thy five
wits! Tom 's acold. O, do de, do de, do de. Bless thee from
whirlwinds, star-blasting, and taking! Do poor Tom some charity,
whom the foul fiend vexes. There could I have him now- and there-
and there again- and there!
Storm still.

blocks.speaker: lear
lines: What, have his daughters brought him to this pass?
Couldst thou save nothing? Didst thou give 'em all?

blocks.speaker: fool-kl
lines: Nay, he reserv'd a blanket, else we had been all sham'd.

blocks.speaker: lear
lines: Now all the plagues that in the pendulous air
Hang fated o'er men's faults light on thy daughters!

blocks.speaker: earlkent
lines: He hath no daughters, sir.

blocks.speaker: lear
lines: Death, traitor! nothing could have subdu'd nature
To such a lowness but his unkind daughters.
Is it the fashion that discarded fathers
Should have thus little mercy on their flesh?
Judicious punishment! 'Twas this flesh begot
Those pelican daughters.

blocks.speaker: edgar
lines: Pillicock sat on Pillicock's Hill. 'Allow, 'allow, loo, loo!

blocks.speaker: fool-kl
lines: This cold night will turn us all to fools and madmen.

blocks.speaker: edgar
lines: Take heed o' th' foul fiend; obey thy parents: keep thy word
justly; swear not; commit not with man's sworn spouse; set not
thy sweet heart on proud array. Tom 's acold.

blocks.speaker: lear
lines: What hast thou been?

blocks.speaker: edgar
lines: A servingman, proud in heart and mind; that curl'd my hair,
wore gloves in my cap; serv'd the lust of my mistress' heart and
did the act of darkness with her; swore as many oaths as I spake
words, and broke them in the sweet face of heaven; one that
slept in the contriving of lust, and wak'd to do it. Wine lov'd
I deeply, dice dearly; and in woman out-paramour'd the Turk.
False of heart, light of ear, bloody of hand; hog in sloth, fox
in stealth, wolf in greediness, dog in madness, lion in prey.
Let not the creaking of shoes nor the rustling of silks betray
thy poor heart to woman. Keep thy foot out of brothel, thy hand
out of placket, thy pen from lender's book, and defy the foul
fiend. Still through the hawthorn blows the cold wind; says
suum, mun, hey, no, nonny. Dolphin my boy, my boy, sessa! let
him trot by.
Storm still.

blocks.speaker: lear
lines: Why, thou wert better in thy grave than to answer with thy
uncover'd body this extremity of the skies. Is man no more than
this? Consider him well. Thou ow'st the worm no silk, the beast
no hide, the sheep no wool, the cat no perfume. Ha! Here's three
on's are sophisticated! Thou art the thing itself;
unaccommodated man is no more but such a poor, bare, forked
animal as thou art. Off, off, you lendings! Come, unbutton
here.
[Tears at his clothes.]

blocks.speaker: fool-kl
lines: Prithee, nuncle, be contented! 'Tis a naughty night to swim
in. Now a little fire in a wild field were like an old lecher's
heart- a small spark, all the rest on's body cold. Look, here
comes a walking fire.
Enter Gloucester with a torch.

blocks.speaker: edgar
lines: This is the foul fiend Flibbertigibbet. He begins at curfew,
and walks till the first cock. He gives the web and the pin,
squints the eye, and makes the harelip; mildews the white wheat,
and hurts the poor creature of earth.
Saint Withold footed thrice the 'old;
He met the nightmare, and her nine fold;
Bid her alight
And her troth plight,
And aroint thee, witch, aroint thee!

blocks.speaker: earlkent
lines: How fares your Grace?

blocks.speaker: lear
lines: What's he?

blocks.speaker: earlkent
lines: Who's there? What is't you seek?

blocks.speaker: glouchester
lines: What are you there? Your names?

blocks.speaker: edgar
lines: Poor Tom, that eats the swimming frog, the toad, the todpole,
the wall-newt and the water; that in the fury of his heart, when
the foul fiend rages, eats cow-dung for sallets, swallows the
old rat and the ditch-dog, drinks the green mantle of the
standing pool; who is whipp'd from tithing to tithing, and
stock-punish'd and imprison'd; who hath had three suits to his
back, six shirts to his body, horse to ride, and weapons to
wear;
But mice and rats, and such small deer,
Have been Tom's food for seven long year.
Beware my follower. Peace, Smulkin! peace, thou fiend!

blocks.speaker: glouchester
lines: What, hath your Grace no better company?

blocks.speaker: edgar
lines: The prince of darkness is a gentleman!
Modo he's call'd, and Mahu.

blocks.speaker: glouchester
lines: Our flesh and blood is grown so vile, my lord,
That it doth hate what gets it.

blocks.speaker: edgar
lines: Poor Tom 's acold.

blocks.speaker: glouchester
lines: Go in with me. My duty cannot suffer
T' obey in all your daughters' hard commands.
Though their injunction be to bar my doors
And let this tyrannous night take hold upon you,
Yet have I ventur'd to come seek you out
And bring you where both fire and food is ready.

blocks.speaker: lear
lines: First let me talk with this philosopher.
What is the cause of thunder?

blocks.speaker: earlkent
lines: Good my lord, take his offer; go into th' house.

blocks.speaker: lear
lines: I'll talk a word with this same learned Theban.
What is your study?

blocks.speaker: edgar
lines: How to prevent the fiend and to kill vermin.

blocks.speaker: lear
lines: Let me ask you one word in private.

blocks.speaker: earlkent
lines: Importune him once more to go, my lord.
His wits begin t' unsettle.

blocks.speaker: glouchester
lines: Canst thou blame him? [Storm still.]
His daughters seek his death. Ah, that good Kent!
He said it would be thus- poor banish'd man!
Thou say'st the King grows mad: I'll tell thee, friend,
I am almost mad myself. I had a son,
Now outlaw'd from my blood. He sought my life
But lately, very late. I lov'd him, friend-
No father his son dearer. True to tell thee,
The grief hath craz'd my wits. What a night 's this!
I do beseech your Grace-

blocks.speaker: lear
lines: O, cry you mercy, sir.
Noble philosopher, your company.

blocks.speaker: edgar
lines: Tom's acold.

blocks.speaker: glouchester
lines: In, fellow, there, into th' hovel; keep thee warm.

blocks.speaker: lear
lines: Come, let's in all.

blocks.speaker: earlkent
lines: This way, my lord.

blocks.speaker: lear
lines: With him!
I will keep still with my philosopher.

blocks.speaker: earlkent
lines: Good my lord, soothe him; let him take the fellow.

blocks.speaker: glouchester
lines: Take him you on.

blocks.speaker: earlkent
lines: Sirrah, come on; go along with us.

blocks.speaker: lear
lines: Come, good Athenian.

blocks.speaker: glouchester
lines: No words, no words! hush.

blocks.speaker: edgar
lines: Child Rowland to the dark tower came;
His word was still
Fie, foh, and fum!
I smell the blood of a British man.
Exeunt.
Enter Cornwall and Edmund.

blocks.speaker: dukecornwall
lines: I will have my revenge ere I depart his house.

blocks.speaker: edmund
lines: How, my lord, I may be censured, that nature thus gives way to
loyalty, something fears me to think of.

blocks.speaker: dukecornwall
lines: I now perceive it was not altogether your brother's evil
disposition made him seek his death; but a provoking merit, set
awork by a reproveable badness in himself.

blocks.speaker: edmund
lines: How malicious is my fortune that I must repent to be just!
This is the letter he spoke of, which approves him an
intelligent party to the advantages of France. O heavens! that
this treason were not- or not I the detector!

blocks.speaker: dukecornwall
lines: Go with me to the Duchess.

blocks.speaker: edmund
lines: If the matter of this paper be certain, you have mighty
business in hand.

blocks.speaker: dukecornwall
lines: True or false, it hath made thee Earl of Gloucester.
Seek out where thy father is, that he may be ready for our
apprehension.

blocks.speaker: edmund
lines: [aside] If I find him comforting the King, it will stuff his
suspicion more fully.- I will persever in my course of loyalty,
though the conflict be sore between that and my blood.

blocks.speaker: dukecornwall
lines: I will lay trust upon thee, and thou shalt find a dearer
father in my love.
Exeunt.
Enter Gloucester, Lear, Kent, Fool, and Edgar.

blocks.speaker: glouchester
lines: Here is better than the open air; take it thankfully. I will
piece out the comfort with what addition I can. I will not be
long from you.

blocks.speaker: earlkent
lines: All the power of his wits have given way to his impatience.
The gods reward your kindness!
Exit [Gloucester].

blocks.speaker: edgar
lines: Frateretto calls me, and tells me Nero is an angler in the
lake of darkness. Pray, innocent, and beware the foul fiend.

blocks.speaker: fool-kl
lines: Prithee, nuncle, tell me whether a madman be a gentleman or a
yeoman.

blocks.speaker: lear
lines: A king, a king!

blocks.speaker: fool-kl
lines: No, he's a yeoman that has a gentleman to his son; for he's a
mad yeoman that sees his son a gentleman before him.

blocks.speaker: lear
lines: To have a thousand with red burning spits
Come hizzing in upon 'em-

blocks.speaker: edgar
lines: The foul fiend bites my back.

blocks.speaker: fool-kl
lines: He's mad that trusts in the tameness of a wolf, a horse's
health, a boy's love, or a whore's oath.

blocks.speaker: lear
lines: It shall be done; I will arraign them straight.
[To Edgar] Come, sit thou here, most learned justicer.
[To the Fool] Thou, sapient sir, sit here. Now, you she-foxes!

blocks.speaker: edgar
lines: Look, where he stands and glares! Want'st thou eyes at trial,
madam?
Come o'er the bourn, Bessy, to me.

blocks.speaker: fool-kl
lines: Her boat hath a leak,
And she must not speak
Why she dares not come over to thee.

blocks.speaker: edgar
lines: The foul fiend haunts poor Tom in the voice of a nightingale.
Hoppedance cries in Tom's belly for two white herring. Croak
not, black angel; I have no food for thee.

blocks.speaker: earlkent
lines: How do you, sir? Stand you not so amaz'd.
Will you lie down and rest upon the cushions?

blocks.speaker: lear
lines: I'll see their trial first. Bring in their evidence.
[To Edgar] Thou, robed man of justice, take thy place.
[To the Fool] And thou, his yokefellow of equity,
Bench by his side. [To Kent] You are o' th' commission,
Sit you too.

blocks.speaker: edgar
lines: Let us deal justly.
Sleepest or wakest thou, jolly shepherd?
Thy sheep be in the corn;
And for one blast of thy minikin mouth
Thy sheep shall take no harm.
Purr! the cat is gray.

blocks.speaker: lear
lines: Arraign her first. 'Tis Goneril. I here take my oath before
this honourable assembly, she kicked the poor King her father.

blocks.speaker: fool-kl
lines: Come hither, mistress. Is your name Goneril?

blocks.speaker: lear
lines: She cannot deny it.

blocks.speaker: fool-kl
lines: Cry you mercy, I took you for a joint-stool.

blocks.speaker: lear
lines: And here's another, whose warp'd looks proclaim
What store her heart is made on. Stop her there!
Arms, arms! sword! fire! Corruption in the place!
False justicer, why hast thou let her scape?

blocks.speaker: edgar
lines: Bless thy five wits!

blocks.speaker: earlkent
lines: O pity! Sir, where is the patience now
That you so oft have boasted to retain?

blocks.speaker: edgar
lines: [aside] My tears begin to take his part so much
They'll mar my counterfeiting.

blocks.speaker: lear
lines: The little dogs and all,
Tray, Blanch, and Sweetheart, see, they bark at me.

blocks.speaker: edgar
lines: Tom will throw his head at them. Avaunt, you curs!
Be thy mouth or black or white,
Tooth that poisons if it bite;
Mastiff, greyhound, mongrel grim,
Hound or spaniel, brach or lym,
Bobtail tyke or trundle-tail-
Tom will make them weep and wail;
For, with throwing thus my head,
Dogs leap the hatch, and all are fled.
Do de, de, de. Sessa! Come, march to wakes and fairs and market
towns. Poor Tom, thy horn is dry.

blocks.speaker: lear
lines: Then let them anatomize Regan. See what breeds about her
heart. Is there any cause in nature that makes these hard
hearts? [To Edgar] You, sir- I entertain you for one of my
hundred; only I do not like the fashion of your garments. You'll
say they are Persian attire; but let them be chang'd.

blocks.speaker: earlkent
lines: Now, good my lord, lie here and rest awhile.

blocks.speaker: lear
lines: Make no noise, make no noise; draw the curtains.
So, so, so. We'll go to supper i' th' morning. So, so, so.

blocks.speaker: fool-kl
lines: And I'll go to bed at noon.
Enter Gloucester.

blocks.speaker: glouchester
lines: Come hither, friend. Where is the King my master?

blocks.speaker: earlkent
lines: Here, sir; but trouble him not; his wits are gone.

blocks.speaker: glouchester
lines: Good friend, I prithee take him in thy arms.
I have o'erheard a plot of death upon him.
There is a litter ready; lay him in't
And drive towards Dover, friend, where thou shalt meet
Both welcome and protection. Take up thy master.
If thou shouldst dally half an hour, his life,
With thine, and all that offer to defend him,
Stand in assured loss. Take up, take up!
And follow me, that will to some provision
Give thee quick conduct.

blocks.speaker: earlkent
lines: Oppressed nature sleeps.
This rest might yet have balm'd thy broken senses,
Which, if convenience will not allow,
Stand in hard cure. [To the Fool] Come, help to bear thy master.
Thou must not stay behind.

blocks.speaker: glouchester
lines: Come, come, away!
Exeunt [all but Edgar].

blocks.speaker: edgar
lines: When we our betters see bearing our woes,
We scarcely think our miseries our foes.
Who alone suffers suffers most i' th' mind,
Leaving free things and happy shows behind;
But then the mind much sufferance doth o'erskip
When grief hath mates, and bearing fellowship.
How light and portable my pain seems now,
When that which makes me bend makes the King bow,
He childed as I fathered! Tom, away!
Mark the high noises, and thyself bewray
When false opinion, whose wrong thought defiles thee,
In thy just proof repeals and reconciles thee.
What will hap more to-night, safe scape the King!
Lurk, lurk.                      [Exit.]

scenes.title: Gloucester’s Castle. Enter Cornwall, Regan, Goneril, [Edmund the] Bastard, and Servants.

blocks.speaker: dukecornwall
lines: [to Goneril] Post speedily to my lord your husband, show him
this letter. The army of France is landed.- Seek out the traitor
Gloucester.
[Exeunt some of the Servants.]

blocks.speaker: regan
lines: Hang him instantly.

blocks.speaker: goneril
lines: Pluck out his eyes.

blocks.speaker: dukecornwall
lines: Leave him to my displeasure. Edmund, keep you our sister
company. The revenges we are bound to take upon your traitorous
father are not fit for your beholding. Advise the Duke where you
are going, to a most festinate preparation. We are bound to the
like. Our posts shall be swift and intelligent betwixt us.
Farewell, dear sister; farewell, my Lord of Gloucester. [Enter Oswald the Steward.]
How now? Where's the King?

blocks.speaker: oswald
lines: My Lord of Gloucester hath convey'd him hence.
Some five or six and thirty of his knights,
Hot questrists after him, met him at gate;
Who, with some other of the lord's dependants,
Are gone with him towards Dover, where they boast
To have well-armed friends.

blocks.speaker: dukecornwall
lines: Get horses for your mistress.

blocks.speaker: goneril
lines: Farewell, sweet lord, and sister.

blocks.speaker: dukecornwall
lines: Edmund, farewell. [Exeunt Goneril, Edmund, and Oswald.]
Go seek the traitor Gloucester,
Pinion him like a thief, bring him before us. [Exeunt other Servants.]
Though well we may not pass upon his life
Without the form of justice, yet our power
Shall do a court'sy to our wrath, which men
May blame, but not control. [Enter Gloucester, brought in by two or three.]
Who's there? the traitor?

blocks.speaker: regan
lines: Ingrateful fox! 'tis he.

blocks.speaker: dukecornwall
lines: Bind fast his corky arms.

blocks.speaker: glouchester
lines: What mean, your Graces? Good my friends, consider
You are my guests. Do me no foul play, friends.

blocks.speaker: dukecornwall
lines: Bind him, I say.
[Servants bind him.]

blocks.speaker: regan
lines: Hard, hard. O filthy traitor!

blocks.speaker: glouchester
lines: Unmerciful lady as you are, I am none.

blocks.speaker: dukecornwall
lines: To this chair bind him. Villain, thou shalt find-
[Regan plucks his beard.]

blocks.speaker: glouchester
lines: By the kind gods, 'tis most ignobly done
To pluck me by the beard.

blocks.speaker: regan
lines: So white, and such a traitor!

blocks.speaker: glouchester
lines: Naughty lady,
These hairs which thou dost ravish from my chin
Will quicken, and accuse thee. I am your host.
With robber's hands my hospitable favours
You should not ruffle thus. What will you do?

blocks.speaker: dukecornwall
lines: Come, sir, what letters had you late from France?

blocks.speaker: regan
lines: Be simple-answer'd, for we know the truth.

blocks.speaker: dukecornwall
lines: And what confederacy have you with the traitors
Late footed in the kingdom?

blocks.speaker: regan
lines: To whose hands have you sent the lunatic King?
Speak.

blocks.speaker: glouchester
lines: I have a letter guessingly set down,
Which came from one that's of a neutral heart,
And not from one oppos'd.

blocks.speaker: dukecornwall
lines: Cunning.

blocks.speaker: regan
lines: And false.

blocks.speaker: dukecornwall
lines: Where hast thou sent the King?

blocks.speaker: glouchester
lines: To Dover.

blocks.speaker: regan
lines: Wherefore to Dover? Wast thou not charg'd at peril-

blocks.speaker: dukecornwall
lines: Wherefore to Dover? Let him first answer that.

blocks.speaker: glouchester
lines: I am tied to th' stake, and I must stand the course.

blocks.speaker: regan
lines: Wherefore to Dover, sir?

blocks.speaker: glouchester
lines: Because I would not see thy cruel nails
Pluck out his poor old eyes; nor thy fierce sister
In his anointed flesh stick boarish fangs.
The sea, with such a storm as his bare head
In hell-black night endur'd, would have buoy'd up
And quench'd the steeled fires.
Yet, poor old heart, he holp the heavens to rain.
If wolves had at thy gate howl'd that stern time,
Thou shouldst have said, 'Good porter, turn the key.'
All cruels else subscrib'd. But I shall see
The winged vengeance overtake such children.

blocks.speaker: dukecornwall
lines: See't shalt thou never. Fellows, hold the chair.
Upon these eyes of thine I'll set my foot.

blocks.speaker: glouchester
lines: He that will think to live till he be old,
Give me some help!- O cruel! O ye gods!

blocks.speaker: regan
lines: One side will mock another. Th' other too!

blocks.speaker: dukecornwall
lines: If you see vengeance-

blocks.speaker: servant1-kl
lines: Hold your hand, my lord!
I have serv'd you ever since I was a child;
But better service have I never done you
Than now to bid you hold.

blocks.speaker: regan
lines: How now, you dog?

blocks.speaker: servant1-kl
lines: If you did wear a beard upon your chin,
I'ld shake it on this quarrel.

blocks.speaker: regan
lines: What do you mean?

blocks.speaker: dukecornwall
lines: My villain!                               Draw and fight.

blocks.speaker: servant1-kl
lines: Nay, then, come on, and take the chance of anger.

blocks.speaker: regan
lines: Give me thy sword. A peasant stand up thus?
She takes a sword and runs at him behind.

blocks.speaker: servant1-kl
lines: O, I am slain! My lord, you have one eye left
To see some mischief on him. O!                     He dies.

blocks.speaker: dukecornwall
lines: Lest it see more, prevent it. Out, vile jelly!
Where is thy lustre now?

blocks.speaker: glouchester
lines: All dark and comfortless! Where's my son Edmund?
Edmund, enkindle all the sparks of nature
To quit this horrid act.

blocks.speaker: regan
lines: Out, treacherous villain!
Thou call'st on him that hates thee. It was he
That made the overture of thy treasons to us;
Who is too good to pity thee.

blocks.speaker: glouchester
lines: O my follies! Then Edgar was abus'd.
Kind gods, forgive me that, and prosper him!

blocks.speaker: regan
lines: Go thrust him out at gates, and let him smell
His way to Dover. [Exit one with Gloucester.]
How is't, my lord? How look you?

blocks.speaker: dukecornwall
lines: I have receiv'd a hurt. Follow me, lady.
Turn out that eyeless villain. Throw this slave
Upon the dunghill. Regan, I bleed apace.
Untimely comes this hurt. Give me your arm.
Exit [Cornwall, led by Regan].

blocks.speaker: servant2-kl
lines: I'll never care what wickedness I do,
If this man come to good.

blocks.speaker: servant3-kl
lines: If she live long,
And in the end meet the old course of death,
Women will all turn monsters.

blocks.speaker: servant2-kl
lines: Let's follow the old Earl, and get the bedlam
To lead him where he would. His roguish madness
Allows itself to anything.

blocks.speaker: servant3-kl
lines: Go thou. I'll fetch some flax and whites of eggs
To apply to his bleeding face. Now heaven help him!
Exeunt.
Enter Edgar.

blocks.speaker: edgar
lines: Yet better thus, and known to be contemn'd,
Than still contemn'd and flatter'd. To be worst,
The lowest and most dejected thing of fortune,
Stands still in esperance, lives not in fear.
The lamentable change is from the best;
The worst returns to laughter. Welcome then,
Thou unsubstantial air that I embrace!
The wretch that thou hast blown unto the worst
Owes nothing to thy blasts.
[Enter Gloucester, led by an Old Man.]
But who comes here?
My father, poorly led? World, world, O world!
But that thy strange mutations make us hate thee,
Life would not yield to age.

blocks.speaker: oldman-kl
lines: O my good lord,
I have been your tenant, and your father's tenant,
These fourscore years.

blocks.speaker: glouchester
lines: Away, get thee away! Good friend, be gone.
Thy comforts can do me no good at all;
Thee they may hurt.

blocks.speaker: oldman-kl
lines: You cannot see your way.

blocks.speaker: glouchester
lines: I have no way, and therefore want no eyes;
I stumbled when I saw. Full oft 'tis seen
Our means secure us, and our mere defects
Prove our commodities. Ah dear son Edgar,
The food of thy abused father's wrath!
Might I but live to see thee in my touch,
I'ld say I had eyes again!

blocks.speaker: oldman-kl
lines: How now? Who's there?

blocks.speaker: edgar
lines: [aside] O gods! Who is't can say 'I am at the worst'?
I am worse than e'er I was.

blocks.speaker: oldman-kl
lines: 'Tis poor mad Tom.

blocks.speaker: edgar
lines: [aside] And worse I may be yet. The worst is not
So long as we can say 'This is the worst.'

blocks.speaker: oldman-kl
lines: Fellow, where goest?

blocks.speaker: glouchester
lines: Is it a beggarman?

blocks.speaker: oldman-kl
lines: Madman and beggar too.

blocks.speaker: glouchester
lines: He has some reason, else he could not beg.
I' th' last night's storm I such a fellow saw,
Which made me think a man a worm. My son
Came then into my mind, and yet my mind
Was then scarce friends with him. I have heard more since.
As flies to wanton boys are we to th' gods.
They kill us for their sport.

blocks.speaker: edgar
lines: [aside] How should this be?
Bad is the trade that must play fool to sorrow,
Ang'ring itself and others.- Bless thee, master!

blocks.speaker: glouchester
lines: Is that the naked fellow?

blocks.speaker: oldman-kl
lines: Ay, my lord.

blocks.speaker: glouchester
lines: Then prithee get thee gone. If for my sake
Thou wilt o'ertake us hence a mile or twain
I' th' way toward Dover, do it for ancient love;
And bring some covering for this naked soul,
Who I'll entreat to lead me.

blocks.speaker: oldman-kl
lines: Alack, sir, he is mad!

blocks.speaker: glouchester
lines: 'Tis the time's plague when madmen lead the blind.
Do as I bid thee, or rather do thy pleasure.
Above the rest, be gone.

blocks.speaker: oldman-kl
lines: I'll bring him the best 'parel that I have,
Come on't what will.               Exit.

blocks.speaker: glouchester
lines: Sirrah naked fellow-

blocks.speaker: edgar
lines: Poor Tom's acold. [Aside] I cannot daub it further.

blocks.speaker: glouchester
lines: Come hither, fellow.

blocks.speaker: edgar
lines: [aside] And yet I must.- Bless thy sweet eyes, they bleed.

blocks.speaker: glouchester
lines: Know'st thou the way to Dover?

blocks.speaker: edgar
lines: Both stile and gate, horseway and footpath. Poor Tom hath been
scar'd out of his good wits. Bless thee, good man's son, from
the foul fiend! Five fiends have been in poor Tom at once: of
lust, as Obidicut; Hobbididence, prince of dumbness; Mahu, of
stealing; Modo, of murder; Flibbertigibbet, of mopping and
mowing, who since possesses chambermaids and waiting women. So,
bless thee, master!

blocks.speaker: glouchester
lines: Here, take this purse, thou whom the heavens' plagues
Have humbled to all strokes. That I am wretched
Makes thee the happier. Heavens, deal so still!
Let the superfluous and lust-dieted man,
That slaves your ordinance, that will not see
Because he does not feel, feel your pow'r quickly;
So distribution should undo excess,
And each man have enough. Dost thou know Dover?

blocks.speaker: edgar
lines: Ay, master.

blocks.speaker: glouchester
lines: There is a cliff, whose high and bending head
Looks fearfully in the confined deep.
Bring me but to the very brim of it,
And I'll repair the misery thou dost bear
With something rich about me. From that place
I shall no leading need.

blocks.speaker: edgar
lines: Give me thy arm.
Poor Tom shall lead thee.
Exeunt.

scenes.title: Before the Duke of Albany’s Palace.

lines: Enter Goneril and [Edmund the] Bastard.

blocks.speaker: goneril
lines: Welcome, my lord. I marvel our mild husband
Not met us on the way. [Enter Oswald the Steward.]
Now, where's your master?

blocks.speaker: oswald
lines: Madam, within, but never man so chang'd.
I told him of the army that was landed:
He smil'd at it. I told him you were coming:
His answer was, 'The worse.' Of Gloucester's treachery
And of the loyal service of his son
When I inform'd him, then he call'd me sot
And told me I had turn'd the wrong side out.
What most he should dislike seems pleasant to him;
What like, offensive.

blocks.speaker: goneril
lines: [to Edmund] Then shall you go no further.
It is the cowish terror of his spirit,
That dares not undertake. He'll not feel wrongs
Which tie him to an answer. Our wishes on the way
May prove effects. Back, Edmund, to my brother.
Hasten his musters and conduct his pow'rs.
I must change arms at home and give the distaff
Into my husband's hands. This trusty servant
Shall pass between us. Ere long you are like to hear
(If you dare venture in your own behalf)
A mistress's command. Wear this. [Gives a favour.]
Spare speech.
Decline your head. This kiss, if it durst speak,
Would stretch thy spirits up into the air.
Conceive, and fare thee well.

blocks.speaker: edmund
lines: Yours in the ranks of death!                        Exit.

blocks.speaker: goneril
lines: My most dear Gloucester!
O, the difference of man and man!
To thee a woman's services are due;
My fool usurps my body.

blocks.speaker: oswald
lines: Madam, here comes my lord.       Exit.
Enter Albany.

blocks.speaker: goneril
lines: I have been worth the whistle.

blocks.speaker: dukealbany
lines: O Goneril,
You are not worth the dust which the rude wind
Blows in your face! I fear your disposition.
That nature which contemns it origin
Cannot be bordered certain in itself.
She that herself will sliver and disbranch
From her material sap, perforce must wither
And come to deadly use.

blocks.speaker: goneril
lines: No more! The text is foolish.

blocks.speaker: dukealbany
lines: Wisdom and goodness to the vile seem vile;
Filths savour but themselves. What have you done?
Tigers, not daughters, what have you perform'd?
A father, and a gracious aged man,
Whose reverence even the head-lugg'd bear would lick,
Most barbarous, most degenerate, have you madded.
Could my good brother suffer you to do it?
A man, a prince, by him so benefited!
If that the heavens do not their visible spirits
Send quickly down to tame these vile offences,
It will come,
Humanity must perforce prey on itself,
Like monsters of the deep.

blocks.speaker: goneril
lines: Milk-liver'd man!
That bear'st a cheek for blows, a head for wrongs;
Who hast not in thy brows an eye discerning
Thine honour from thy suffering; that not know'st
Fools do those villains pity who are punish'd
Ere they have done their mischief. Where's thy drum?
France spreads his banners in our noiseless land,
With plumed helm thy state begins to threat,
Whiles thou, a moral fool, sit'st still, and criest
'Alack, why does he so?'

blocks.speaker: dukealbany
lines: See thyself, devil!
Proper deformity seems not in the fiend
So horrid as in woman.

blocks.speaker: goneril
lines: O vain fool!

blocks.speaker: dukealbany
lines: Thou changed and self-cover'd thing, for shame!
Bemonster not thy feature! Were't my fitness
To let these hands obey my blood,
They are apt enough to dislocate and tear
Thy flesh and bones. Howe'er thou art a fiend,
A woman's shape doth shield thee.

blocks.speaker: goneril
lines: Marry, your manhood mew!
Enter a Gentleman.

blocks.speaker: dukealbany
lines: What news?

blocks.speaker: gentleman-kl
lines: O, my good lord, the Duke of Cornwall 's dead,
Slain by his servant, going to put out
The other eye of Gloucester.

blocks.speaker: dukealbany
lines: Gloucester's eyes?

blocks.speaker: gentleman-kl
lines: A servant that he bred, thrill'd with remorse,
Oppos'd against the act, bending his sword
To his great master; who, thereat enrag'd,
Flew on him, and amongst them fell'd him dead;
But not without that harmful stroke which since
Hath pluck'd him after.

blocks.speaker: dukealbany
lines: This shows you are above,
You justicers, that these our nether crimes
So speedily can venge! But O poor Gloucester!
Lose he his other eye?

blocks.speaker: gentleman-kl
lines: Both, both, my lord.
This letter, madam, craves a speedy answer.
'Tis from your sister.

blocks.speaker: goneril
lines: [aside] One way I like this well;
But being widow, and my Gloucester with her,
May all the building in my fancy pluck
Upon my hateful life. Another way
The news is not so tart.- I'll read, and answer. Exit.

blocks.speaker: dukealbany
lines: Where was his son when they did take his eyes?

blocks.speaker: gentleman-kl
lines: Come with my lady hither.

blocks.speaker: dukealbany
lines: He is not here.

blocks.speaker: gentleman-kl
lines: No, my good lord; I met him back again.

blocks.speaker: dukealbany
lines: Knows he the wickedness?

blocks.speaker: gentleman-kl
lines: Ay, my good lord. 'Twas he inform'd against him,
And quit the house on purpose, that their punishment
Might have the freer course.

blocks.speaker: dukealbany
lines: Gloucester, I live
To thank thee for the love thou show'dst the King,
And to revenge thine eyes. Come hither, friend.
Tell me what more thou know'st.
Exeunt.
Enter Kent and a Gentleman.

blocks.speaker: earlkent
lines: Why the King of France is so suddenly gone back know you the
reason?

blocks.speaker: gentleman-kl
lines: Something he left imperfect in the state, which since his
coming forth is thought of, which imports to the kingdom so much
fear and danger that his personal return was most required and
necessary.

blocks.speaker: earlkent
lines: Who hath he left behind him general?

blocks.speaker: gentleman-kl
lines: The Marshal of France, Monsieur La Far.

blocks.speaker: earlkent
lines: Did your letters pierce the Queen to any demonstration of
grief?

blocks.speaker: gentleman-kl
lines: Ay, sir. She took them, read them in my presence,
And now and then an ample tear trill'd down
Her delicate cheek. It seem'd she was a queen
Over her passion, who, most rebel-like,
Sought to be king o'er her.

blocks.speaker: earlkent
lines: O, then it mov'd her?

blocks.speaker: gentleman-kl
lines: Not to a rage. Patience and sorrow strove
Who should express her goodliest. You have seen
Sunshine and rain at once: her smiles and tears
Were like, a better way. Those happy smilets
That play'd on her ripe lip seem'd not to know
What guests were in her eyes, which parted thence
As pearls from diamonds dropp'd. In brief,
Sorrow would be a rarity most belov'd,
If all could so become it.

blocks.speaker: earlkent
lines: Made she no verbal question?

blocks.speaker: gentleman-kl
lines: Faith, once or twice she heav'd the name of father
Pantingly forth, as if it press'd her heart;
Cried 'Sisters, sisters! Shame of ladies! Sisters!
Kent! father! sisters! What, i' th' storm? i' th' night?
Let pity not be believ'd!' There she shook
The holy water from her heavenly eyes,
And clamour moisten'd. Then away she started
To deal with grief alone.

blocks.speaker: earlkent
lines: It is the stars,
The stars above us, govern our conditions;
Else one self mate and mate could not beget
Such different issues. You spoke not with her since?

blocks.speaker: gentleman-kl
lines: No.

blocks.speaker: earlkent
lines: Was this before the King return'd?

blocks.speaker: gentleman-kl
lines: No, since.

blocks.speaker: earlkent
lines: Well, sir, the poor distressed Lear's i' th' town;
Who sometime, in his better tune, remembers
What we are come about, and by no means
Will yield to see his daughter.

blocks.speaker: gentleman-kl
lines: Why, good sir?

blocks.speaker: earlkent
lines: A sovereign shame so elbows him; his own unkindness,
That stripp'd her from his benediction, turn'd her
To foreign casualties, gave her dear rights
To his dog-hearted daughters- these things sting
His mind so venomously that burning shame
Detains him from Cordelia.

blocks.speaker: gentleman-kl
lines: Alack, poor gentleman!

blocks.speaker: earlkent
lines: Of Albany's and Cornwall's powers you heard not?

blocks.speaker: gentleman-kl
lines: 'Tis so; they are afoot.

blocks.speaker: earlkent
lines: Well, sir, I'll bring you to our master Lear
And leave you to attend him. Some dear cause
Will in concealment wrap me up awhile.
When I am known aright, you shall not grieve
Lending me this acquaintance. I pray you go
Along with me.                   Exeunt.
Enter, with Drum and Colours, Cordelia, Doctor, and Soldiers.

blocks.speaker: cordelia
lines: Alack, 'tis he! Why, he was met even now
As mad as the vex'd sea, singing aloud,
Crown'd with rank fumiter and furrow weeds,
With harlocks, hemlock, nettles, cuckoo flow'rs,
Darnel, and all the idle weeds that grow
In our sustaining corn. A century send forth.
Search every acre in the high-grown field
And bring him to our eye. [Exit an Officer.] What can man's
wisdom
In the restoring his bereaved sense?
He that helps him take all my outward worth.

blocks.speaker: doctor-kl
lines: There is means, madam.
Our foster nurse of nature is repose,
The which he lacks. That to provoke in him
Are many simples operative, whose power
Will close the eye of anguish.

blocks.speaker: cordelia
lines: All blest secrets,
All you unpublish'd virtues of the earth,
Spring with my tears! be aidant and remediate
In the good man's distress! Seek, seek for him!
Lest his ungovern'd rage dissolve the life
That wants the means to lead it.
Enter Messenger.

blocks.speaker: messenger-kl
lines: News, madam.
The British pow'rs are marching hitherward.

blocks.speaker: cordelia
lines: 'Tis known before. Our preparation stands
In expectation of them. O dear father,
It is thy business that I go about.
Therefore great France
My mourning and important tears hath pitied.
No blown ambition doth our arms incite,
But love, dear love, and our ag'd father's right.
Soon may I hear and see him!
Exeunt.
Enter Regan and [Oswald the] Steward.

blocks.speaker: regan
lines: But are my brother's pow'rs set forth?

blocks.speaker: oswald
lines: Ay, madam.

blocks.speaker: regan
lines: Himself in person there?

blocks.speaker: oswald
lines: Madam, with much ado.
Your sister is the better soldier.

blocks.speaker: regan
lines: Lord Edmund spake not with your lord at home?

blocks.speaker: oswald
lines: No, madam.

blocks.speaker: regan
lines: What might import my sister's letter to him?

blocks.speaker: oswald
lines: I know not, lady.

blocks.speaker: regan
lines: Faith, he is posted hence on serious matter.
It was great ignorance, Gloucester's eyes being out,
To let him live. Where he arrives he moves
All hearts against us. Edmund, I think, is gone,
In pity of his misery, to dispatch
His nighted life; moreover, to descry
The strength o' th' enemy.

blocks.speaker: oswald
lines: I must needs after him, madam, with my letter.

blocks.speaker: regan
lines: Our troops set forth to-morrow. Stay with us.
The ways are dangerous.

blocks.speaker: oswald
lines: I may not, madam.
My lady charg'd my duty in this business.

blocks.speaker: regan
lines: Why should she write to Edmund? Might not you
Transport her purposes by word? Belike,
Something- I know not what- I'll love thee much-
Let me unseal the letter.

blocks.speaker: oswald
lines: Madam, I had rather-

blocks.speaker: regan
lines: I know your lady does not love her husband;
I am sure of that; and at her late being here
She gave strange eyeliads and most speaking looks
To noble Edmund. I know you are of her bosom.

blocks.speaker: oswald
lines: I, madam?

blocks.speaker: regan
lines: I speak in understanding. Y'are! I know't.
Therefore I do advise you take this note.
My lord is dead; Edmund and I have talk'd,
And more convenient is he for my hand
Than for your lady's. You may gather more.
If you do find him, pray you give him this;
And when your mistress hears thus much from you,
I pray desire her call her wisdom to her.
So farewell.
If you do chance to hear of that blind traitor,
Preferment falls on him that cuts him off.

blocks.speaker: oswald
lines: Would I could meet him, madam! I should show
What party I do follow.

blocks.speaker: regan
lines: Fare thee well.                Exeunt.

scenes.title: The country near Dover. Enter Gloucester, and Edgar [like a Peasant].

blocks.speaker: glouchester
lines: When shall I come to th' top of that same hill?

blocks.speaker: edgar
lines: You do climb up it now. Look how we labour.

blocks.speaker: glouchester
lines: Methinks the ground is even.

blocks.speaker: edgar
lines: Horrible steep.
Hark, do you hear the sea?

blocks.speaker: glouchester
lines: No, truly.

blocks.speaker: edgar
lines: Why, then, your other senses grow imperfect
By your eyes' anguish.

blocks.speaker: glouchester
lines: So may it be indeed.
Methinks thy voice is alter'd, and thou speak'st
In better phrase and matter than thou didst.

blocks.speaker: edgar
lines: Y'are much deceiv'd. In nothing am I chang'd
But in my garments.

blocks.speaker: glouchester
lines: Methinks y'are better spoken.

blocks.speaker: edgar
lines: Come on, sir; here's the place. Stand still. How fearful
And dizzy 'tis to cast one's eyes so low!
The crows and choughs that wing the midway air
Show scarce so gross as beetles. Halfway down
Hangs one that gathers sampire- dreadful trade!
Methinks he seems no bigger than his head.
The fishermen that walk upon the beach
Appear like mice; and yond tall anchoring bark,
Diminish'd to her cock; her cock, a buoy
Almost too small for sight. The murmuring surge
That on th' unnumb'red idle pebble chafes
Cannot be heard so high. I'll look no more,
Lest my brain turn, and the deficient sight
Topple down headlong.

blocks.speaker: glouchester
lines: Set me where you stand.

blocks.speaker: edgar
lines: Give me your hand. You are now within a foot
Of th' extreme verge. For all beneath the moon
Would I not leap upright.

blocks.speaker: glouchester
lines: Let go my hand.
Here, friend, is another purse; in it a jewel
Well worth a poor man's taking. Fairies and gods
Prosper it with thee! Go thou further off;
Bid me farewell, and let me hear thee going.

blocks.speaker: edgar
lines: Now fare ye well, good sir.

blocks.speaker: glouchester
lines: With all my heart.

blocks.speaker: edgar
lines: [aside]. Why I do trifle thus with his despair
Is done to cure it.

blocks.speaker: glouchester
lines: O you mighty gods!                            He kneels.
This world I do renounce, and, in your sights,
Shake patiently my great affliction off.
If I could bear it longer and not fall
To quarrel with your great opposeless wills,
My snuff and loathed part of nature should
Burn itself out. If Edgar live, O, bless him!
Now, fellow, fare thee well.
He falls [forward and swoons].

blocks.speaker: edgar
lines: Gone, sir, farewell.-
And yet I know not how conceit may rob
The treasury of life when life itself
Yields to the theft. Had he been where he thought,
By this had thought been past.- Alive or dead?
Ho you, sir! friend! Hear you, sir? Speak!-
Thus might he pass indeed. Yet he revives.
What are you, sir?

blocks.speaker: glouchester
lines: Away, and let me die.

blocks.speaker: edgar
lines: Hadst thou been aught but gossamer, feathers, air,
So many fadom down precipitating,
Thou'dst shiver'd like an egg; but thou dost breathe;
Hast heavy substance; bleed'st not; speak'st; art sound.
Ten masts at each make not the altitude
Which thou hast perpendicularly fell.
Thy life is a miracle. Speak yet again.

blocks.speaker: glouchester
lines: But have I fall'n, or no?

blocks.speaker: edgar
lines: From the dread summit of this chalky bourn.
Look up a-height. The shrill-gorg'd lark so far
Cannot be seen or heard. Do but look up.

blocks.speaker: glouchester
lines: Alack, I have no eyes!
Is wretchedness depriv'd that benefit
To end itself by death? 'Twas yet some comfort
When misery could beguile the tyrant's rage
And frustrate his proud will.

blocks.speaker: edgar
lines: Give me your arm.
Up- so. How is't? Feel you your legs? You stand.

blocks.speaker: glouchester
lines: Too well, too well.

blocks.speaker: edgar
lines: This is above all strangeness.
Upon the crown o' th' cliff what thing was that
Which parted from you?

blocks.speaker: glouchester
lines: A poor unfortunate beggar.

blocks.speaker: edgar
lines: As I stood here below, methought his eyes
Were two full moons; he had a thousand noses,Horns whelk'd and wav'd like the enridged sea.
It was some fiend. Therefore, thou happy father,
Think that the clearest gods, who make them honours
Of men's impossibility, have preserv'd thee.

blocks.speaker: glouchester
lines: I do remember now. Henceforth I'll bear
Affliction till it do cry out itself
'Enough, enough,' and die. That thing you speak of,
I took it for a man. Often 'twould say
'The fiend, the fiend'- he led me to that place.

blocks.speaker: edgar
lines: Bear free and patient thoughts.
Enter Lear, mad, [fantastically dressed with weeds].
But who comes here?
The safer sense will ne'er accommodate
His master thus.

blocks.speaker: lear
lines: No, they cannot touch me for coming;
I am the King himself.

blocks.speaker: edgar
lines: O thou side-piercing sight!

blocks.speaker: lear
lines: Nature 's above art in that respect. There's your press
money. That fellow handles his bow like a crow-keeper. Draw me
a clothier's yard. Look, look, a mouse! Peace, peace; this piece
of toasted cheese will do't. There's my gauntlet; I'll prove it
on a giant. Bring up the brown bills. O, well flown, bird! i'
th' clout, i' th' clout! Hewgh! Give the word.

blocks.speaker: edgar
lines: Sweet marjoram.

blocks.speaker: lear
lines: Pass.

blocks.speaker: glouchester
lines: I know that voice.

blocks.speaker: lear
lines: Ha! Goneril with a white beard? They flatter'd me like a dog,
and told me I had white hairs in my beard ere the black ones
were there. To say 'ay' and 'no' to everything I said! 'Ay' and
'no' too was no good divinity. When the rain came to wet me
once, and the wind to make me chatter; when the thunder would
not peace at my bidding; there I found 'em, there I smelt 'em
out. Go to, they are not men o' their words! They told me I was
everything. 'Tis a lie- I am not ague-proof.

blocks.speaker: glouchester
lines: The trick of that voice I do well remember.
Is't not the King?

blocks.speaker: lear
lines: Ay, every inch a king!
When I do stare, see how the subject quakes.
I pardon that man's life. What was thy cause?
Adultery?
Thou shalt not die. Die for adultery? No.
The wren goes to't, and the small gilded fly
Does lecher in my sight.
Let copulation thrive; for Gloucester's bastard son
Was kinder to his father than my daughters
Got 'tween the lawful sheets.
To't, luxury, pell-mell! for I lack soldiers.
Behold yond simp'ring dame,
Whose face between her forks presageth snow,
That minces virtue, and does shake the head
To hear of pleasure's name.
The fitchew nor the soiled horse goes to't
With a more riotous appetite.
Down from the waist they are Centaurs,
Though women all above.
But to the girdle do the gods inherit,
Beneath is all the fiend's.
There's hell, there's darkness, there's the sulphurous pit;
burning, scalding, stench, consumption. Fie, fie, fie! pah, pah!
Give me an ounce of civet, good apothecary, to sweeten my
imagination. There's money for thee.

blocks.speaker: glouchester
lines: O, let me kiss that hand!

blocks.speaker: lear
lines: Let me wipe it first; it smells of mortality.

blocks.speaker: glouchester
lines: O ruin'd piece of nature! This great world
Shall so wear out to naught. Dost thou know me?

blocks.speaker: lear
lines: I remember thine eyes well enough. Dost thou squiny at me?
No, do thy worst, blind Cupid! I'll not love. Read thou this
challenge; mark but the penning of it.

blocks.speaker: glouchester
lines: Were all the letters suns, I could not see one.

blocks.speaker: edgar
lines: [aside] I would not take this from report. It is,
And my heart breaks at it.

blocks.speaker: lear
lines: Read.

blocks.speaker: glouchester
lines: What, with the case of eyes?

blocks.speaker: lear
lines: O, ho, are you there with me? No eyes in your head, nor no
money in your purse? Your eyes are in a heavy case, your purse
in a light. Yet you see how this world goes.

blocks.speaker: glouchester
lines: I see it feelingly.

blocks.speaker: lear
lines: What, art mad? A man may see how the world goes with no eyes.
Look with thine ears. See how yond justice rails upon yond
simple thief. Hark in thine ear. Change places and, handy-dandy,
which is the justice, which is the thief? Thou hast seen a
farmer's dog bark at a beggar?

blocks.speaker: glouchester
lines: Ay, sir.

blocks.speaker: lear
lines: And the creature run from the cur? There thou mightst behold
the great image of authority: a dog's obeyed in office.
Thou rascal beadle, hold thy bloody hand!
Why dost thou lash that whore? Strip thine own back.
Thou hotly lusts to use her in that kind
For which thou whip'st her. The usurer hangs the cozener.
Through tatter'd clothes small vices do appear;
Robes and furr'd gowns hide all. Plate sin with gold,
And the strong lance of justice hurtless breaks;
Arm it in rags, a pygmy's straw does pierce it.
None does offend, none- I say none! I'll able 'em.
Take that of me, my friend, who have the power
To seal th' accuser's lips. Get thee glass eyes
And, like a scurvy politician, seem
To see the things thou dost not. Now, now, now, now!
Pull off my boots. Harder, harder! So.

blocks.speaker: edgar
lines: O, matter and impertinency mix'd!
Reason, in madness!

blocks.speaker: lear
lines: If thou wilt weep my fortunes, take my eyes.
I know thee well enough; thy name is Gloucester.
Thou must be patient. We came crying hither;
Thou know'st, the first time that we smell the air
We wawl and cry. I will preach to thee. Mark.

blocks.speaker: glouchester
lines: Alack, alack the day!

blocks.speaker: lear
lines: When we are born, we cry that we are come
To this great stage of fools. This' a good block.
It were a delicate stratagem to shoe
A troop of horse with felt. I'll put't in proof,
And when I have stol'n upon these sons-in-law,
Then kill, kill, kill, kill, kill, kill!
Enter a Gentleman [with Attendants].

blocks.speaker: gentleman-kl
lines: O, here he is! Lay hand upon him.- Sir,
Your most dear daughter-

blocks.speaker: lear
lines: No rescue? What, a prisoner? I am even
The natural fool of fortune. Use me well;
You shall have ransom. Let me have a surgeon;
I am cut to th' brains.

blocks.speaker: gentleman-kl
lines: You shall have anything.

blocks.speaker: lear
lines: No seconds? All myself?
Why, this would make a man a man of salt,
To use his eyes for garden waterpots,
Ay, and laying autumn's dust.

blocks.speaker: gentleman-kl
lines: Good sir-

blocks.speaker: lear
lines: I will die bravely, like a smug bridegroom. What!
I will be jovial. Come, come, I am a king;
My masters, know you that?

blocks.speaker: gentleman-kl
lines: You are a royal one, and we obey you.

blocks.speaker: lear
lines: Then there's life in't. Nay, an you get it, you shall get it
by running. Sa, sa, sa, sa!
Exit running. [Attendants follow.]

blocks.speaker: gentleman-kl
lines: A sight most pitiful in the meanest wretch,
Past speaking of in a king! Thou hast one daughter
Who redeems nature from the general curse
Which twain have brought her to.

blocks.speaker: edgar
lines: Hail, gentle sir.

blocks.speaker: gentleman-kl
lines: Sir, speed you. What's your will?

blocks.speaker: edgar
lines: Do you hear aught, sir, of a battle toward?

blocks.speaker: gentleman-kl
lines: Most sure and vulgar. Every one hears that
Which can distinguish sound.

blocks.speaker: edgar
lines: But, by your favour,
How near's the other army?

blocks.speaker: gentleman-kl
lines: Near and on speedy foot. The main descry
Stands on the hourly thought.

blocks.speaker: edgar
lines: I thank you sir. That's all.

blocks.speaker: gentleman-kl
lines: Though that the Queen on special cause is here,
Her army is mov'd on.

blocks.speaker: edgar
lines: I thank you, sir
Exit [Gentleman].

blocks.speaker: glouchester
lines: You ever-gentle gods, take my breath from me;
Let not my worser spirit tempt me again
To die before you please!

blocks.speaker: edgar
lines: Well pray you, father.

blocks.speaker: glouchester
lines: Now, good sir, what are you?

blocks.speaker: edgar
lines: A most poor man, made tame to fortune's blows,
Who, by the art of known and feeling sorrows,
Am pregnant to good pity. Give me your hand;
I'll lead you to some biding.

blocks.speaker: glouchester
lines: Hearty thanks.
The bounty and the benison of heaven
To boot, and boot!
Enter [Oswald the] Steward.

blocks.speaker: oswald
lines: A proclaim'd prize! Most happy!
That eyeless head of thine was first fram'd flesh
To raise my fortunes. Thou old unhappy traitor,
Briefly thyself remember. The sword is out
That must destroy thee.

blocks.speaker: glouchester
lines: Now let thy friendly hand
Put strength enough to't.
[Edgar interposes.]

blocks.speaker: oswald
lines: Wherefore, bold peasant,
Dar'st thou support a publish'd traitor? Hence!
Lest that th' infection of his fortune take
Like hold on thee. Let go his arm.

blocks.speaker: edgar
lines: Chill not let go, zir, without vurther 'cagion.

blocks.speaker: oswald
lines: Let go, slave, or thou diest!

blocks.speaker: edgar
lines: Good gentleman, go your gait, and let poor voke pass. An chud
ha' bin zwagger'd out of my life, 'twould not ha' bin zo long as
'tis by a vortnight. Nay, come not near th' old man. Keep out,
che vore ye, or Ise try whether your costard or my ballow be the
harder. Chill be plain with you.

blocks.speaker: oswald
lines: Out, dunghill!
They fight.

blocks.speaker: edgar
lines: Chill pick your teeth, zir. Come! No matter vor your foins.
[Oswald falls.]

blocks.speaker: oswald
lines: Slave, thou hast slain me. Villain, take my purse.
If ever thou wilt thrive, bury my body,
And give the letters which thou find'st about me
To Edmund Earl of Gloucester. Seek him out
Upon the British party. O, untimely death! Death!
He dies.

blocks.speaker: edgar
lines: I know thee well. A serviceable villain,
As duteous to the vices of thy mistress
As badness would desire.

blocks.speaker: glouchester
lines: What, is he dead?

blocks.speaker: edgar
lines: Sit you down, father; rest you.
Let's see his pockets; these letters that he speaks of
May be my friends. He's dead. I am only sorry
He had no other deathsman. Let us see.
Leave, gentle wax; and, manners, blame us not.
To know our enemies' minds, we'ld rip their hearts;
Their papers, is more lawful. Reads the letter.
'Let our reciprocal vows be rememb'red. You have many
opportunities to cut him off. If your will want not, time and
place will be fruitfully offer'd. There is nothing done, if he
return the conqueror. Then am I the prisoner, and his bed my
jail; from the loathed warmth whereof deliver me, and supply the
place for your labour.
'Your (wife, so I would say) affectionate servant, 'Goneril.'
O indistinguish'd space of woman's will!
A plot upon her virtuous husband's life,
And the exchange my brother! Here in the sands
Thee I'll rake up, the post unsanctified
Of murtherous lechers; and in the mature time
With this ungracious paper strike the sight
Of the death-practis'd Duke, For him 'tis well
That of thy death and business I can tell.

blocks.speaker: glouchester
lines: The King is mad. How stiff is my vile sense,
That I stand up, and have ingenious feeling
Of my huge sorrows! Better I were distract.
So should my thoughts be sever'd from my griefs,
And woes by wrong imaginations lose
The knowledge of themselves.
A drum afar off.

blocks.speaker: edgar
lines: Give me your hand.
Far off methinks I hear the beaten drum.
Come, father, I'll bestow you with a friend. Exeunt.

scenes.title: A tent in the French camp.

lines: Enter Cordelia, Kent, Doctor, and Gentleman.

blocks.speaker: cordelia
lines: O thou good Kent, how shall I live and work
To match thy goodness? My life will be too short
And every measure fail me.

blocks.speaker: earlkent
lines: To be acknowledg'd, madam, is o'erpaid.
All my reports go with the modest truth;
Nor more nor clipp'd, but so.

blocks.speaker: cordelia
lines: Be better suited.
These weeds are memories of those worser hours.
I prithee put them off.

blocks.speaker: earlkent
lines: Pardon, dear madam.
Yet to be known shortens my made intent.
My boon I make it that you know me not
Till time and I think meet.

blocks.speaker: cordelia
lines: Then be't so, my good lord. [To the Doctor] How, does the King?

blocks.speaker: doctor-kl
lines: Madam, sleeps still.

blocks.speaker: cordelia
lines: O you kind gods,
Cure this great breach in his abused nature!
Th' untun'd and jarring senses, O, wind up
Of this child-changed father!

blocks.speaker: doctor-kl
lines: So please your Majesty
That we may wake the King? He hath slept long.

blocks.speaker: cordelia
lines: Be govern'd by your knowledge, and proceed
I' th' sway of your own will. Is he array'd?
Enter Lear in a chair carried by Servants.

blocks.speaker: gentleman-kl
lines: Ay, madam. In the heaviness of sleep
We put fresh garments on him.

blocks.speaker: doctor-kl
lines: Be by, good madam, when we do awake him.
I doubt not of his temperance.

blocks.speaker: cordelia
lines: Very well.
Music.

blocks.speaker: doctor-kl
lines: Please you draw near. Louder the music there!

blocks.speaker: cordelia
lines: O my dear father, restoration hang
Thy medicine on my lips, and let this kiss
Repair those violent harms that my two sisters
Have in thy reverence made!

blocks.speaker: earlkent
lines: Kind and dear princess!

blocks.speaker: cordelia
lines: Had you not been their father, these white flakes
Had challeng'd pity of them. Was this a face
To be oppos'd against the warring winds?
To stand against the deep dread-bolted thunder?
In the most terrible and nimble stroke
Of quick cross lightning? to watch- poor perdu!-
With this thin helm? Mine enemy's dog,
Though he had bit me, should have stood that night
Against my fire; and wast thou fain, poor father,
To hovel thee with swine and rogues forlorn,
In short and musty straw? Alack, alack!
'Tis wonder that thy life and wits at once
Had not concluded all.- He wakes. Speak to him.

blocks.speaker: doctor-kl
lines: Madam, do you; 'tis fittest.

blocks.speaker: cordelia
lines: How does my royal lord? How fares your Majesty?

blocks.speaker: lear
lines: You do me wrong to take me out o' th' grave.
Thou art a soul in bliss; but I am bound
Upon a wheel of fire, that mine own tears
Do scald like molten lead.

blocks.speaker: cordelia
lines: Sir, do you know me?

blocks.speaker: lear
lines: You are a spirit, I know. When did you die?

blocks.speaker: cordelia
lines: Still, still, far wide!

blocks.speaker: doctor-kl
lines: He's scarce awake. Let him alone awhile.

blocks.speaker: lear
lines: Where have I been? Where am I? Fair daylight,
I am mightily abus'd. I should e'en die with pity,
To see another thus. I know not what to say.
I will not swear these are my hands. Let's see.
I feel this pin prick. Would I were assur'd
Of my condition!

blocks.speaker: cordelia
lines: O, look upon me, sir,
And hold your hands in benediction o'er me.
No, sir, you must not kneel.

blocks.speaker: lear
lines: Pray, do not mock me.
I am a very foolish fond old man,
Fourscore and upward, not an hour more nor less;
And, to deal plainly,
I fear I am not in my perfect mind.
Methinks I should know you, and know this man;
Yet I am doubtful; for I am mainly ignorant
What place this is; and all the skill I have
Remembers not these garments; nor I know not
Where I did lodge last night. Do not laugh at me;
For (as I am a man) I think this lady
To be my child Cordelia.

blocks.speaker: cordelia
lines: And so I am! I am!

blocks.speaker: lear
lines: Be your tears wet? Yes, faith. I pray weep not.
If you have poison for me, I will drink it.
I know you do not love me; for your sisters
Have, as I do remember, done me wrong.
You have some cause, they have not.

blocks.speaker: cordelia
lines: No cause, no cause.

blocks.speaker: lear
lines: Am I in France?

blocks.speaker: earlkent
lines: In your own kingdom, sir.

blocks.speaker: lear
lines: Do not abuse me.

blocks.speaker: doctor-kl
lines: Be comforted, good madam. The great rage
You see is kill'd in him; and yet it is danger
To make him even o'er the time he has lost.
Desire him to go in. Trouble him no more
Till further settling.

blocks.speaker: cordelia
lines: Will't please your Highness walk?

blocks.speaker: lear
lines: You must bear with me.
Pray you now, forget and forgive. I am old and foolish.
Exeunt. Manent Kent and Gentleman.

blocks.speaker: gentleman-kl
lines: Holds it true, sir, that the Duke of Cornwall was so slain?

blocks.speaker: earlkent
lines: Most certain, sir.

blocks.speaker: gentleman-kl
lines: Who is conductor of his people?

blocks.speaker: earlkent
lines: As 'tis said, the bastard son of Gloucester.

blocks.speaker: gentleman-kl
lines: They say Edgar, his banish'd son, is with the Earl of Kent
in Germany.

blocks.speaker: earlkent
lines: Report is changeable. 'Tis time to look about; the powers of
the kingdom approach apace.

blocks.speaker: gentleman-kl
lines: The arbitrement is like to be bloody.
Fare you well, sir.              [Exit.]

blocks.speaker: earlkent
lines: My point and period will be throughly wrought,
Or well or ill, as this day's battle's fought. Exit.
Enter, with Drum and Colours, Edmund, Regan, Gentleman, and Soldiers.

blocks.speaker: edmund
lines: Know of the Duke if his last purpose hold,
Or whether since he is advis'd by aught
To change the course. He's full of alteration
And self-reproving. Bring his constant pleasure.
[Exit an Officer.]

blocks.speaker: regan
lines: Our sister's man is certainly miscarried.

blocks.speaker: edmund
lines: Tis to be doubted, madam.

blocks.speaker: regan
lines: Now, sweet lord,
You know the goodness I intend upon you.
Tell me- but truly- but then speak the truth-
Do you not love my sister?

blocks.speaker: edmund
lines: In honour'd love.

blocks.speaker: regan
lines: But have you never found my brother's way
To the forfended place?

blocks.speaker: edmund
lines: That thought abuses you.

blocks.speaker: regan
lines: I am doubtful that you have been conjunct
And bosom'd with her, as far as we call hers.

blocks.speaker: edmund
lines: No, by mine honour, madam.

blocks.speaker: regan
lines: I never shall endure her. Dear my lord,
Be not familiar with her.

blocks.speaker: edmund
lines: Fear me not.
She and the Duke her husband!
Enter, with Drum and Colours, Albany, Goneril, Soldiers.

blocks.speaker: goneril
lines: [aside] I had rather lose the battle than that sister
Should loosen him and me.

blocks.speaker: dukealbany
lines: Our very loving sister, well bemet.
Sir, this I hear: the King is come to his daughter,
With others whom the rigour of our state
Forc'd to cry out. Where I could not be honest,
I never yet was valiant. For this business,
It toucheth us as France invades our land,
Not bolds the King, with others whom, I fear,
Most just and heavy causes make oppose.

blocks.speaker: edmund
lines: Sir, you speak nobly.

blocks.speaker: regan
lines: Why is this reason'd?

blocks.speaker: goneril
lines: Combine together 'gainst the enemy;
For these domestic and particular broils
Are not the question here.

blocks.speaker: dukealbany
lines: Let's then determine
With th' ancient of war on our proceeding.

blocks.speaker: edmund
lines: I shall attend you presently at your tent.

blocks.speaker: regan
lines: Sister, you'll go with us?

blocks.speaker: goneril
lines: No.

blocks.speaker: regan
lines: 'Tis most convenient. Pray you go with us.

blocks.speaker: goneril
lines: [aside] O, ho, I know the riddle.- I will go.
[As they are going out,] enter Edgar [disguised].

blocks.speaker: edgar
lines: If e'er your Grace had speech with man so poor,
Hear me one word.

blocks.speaker: dukealbany
lines: I'll overtake you.- Speak.
Exeunt [all but Albany and Edgar].

blocks.speaker: edgar
lines: Before you fight the battle, ope this letter.
If you have victory, let the trumpet sound
For him that brought it. Wretched though I seem,
I can produce a champion that will prove
What is avouched there. If you miscarry,
Your business of the world hath so an end,
And machination ceases. Fortune love you!

blocks.speaker: dukealbany
lines: Stay till I have read the letter.

blocks.speaker: edgar
lines: I was forbid it.
When time shall serve, let but the herald cry,
And I'll appear again.

blocks.speaker: dukealbany
lines: Why, fare thee well. I will o'erlook thy paper.
Exit [Edgar].
Enter Edmund.

blocks.speaker: edmund
lines: The enemy 's in view; draw up your powers.
Here is the guess of their true strength and forces
By diligent discovery; but your haste
Is now urg'd on you.

blocks.speaker: dukealbany
lines: We will greet the time.          Exit.

blocks.speaker: edmund
lines: To both these sisters have I sworn my love;
Each jealous of the other, as the stung
Are of the adder. Which of them shall I take?
Both? one? or neither? Neither can be enjoy'd,
If both remain alive. To take the widow
Exasperates, makes mad her sister Goneril;
And hardly shall I carry out my side,
Her husband being alive. Now then, we'll use
His countenance for the battle, which being done,
Let her who would be rid of him devise
His speedy taking off. As for the mercy
Which he intends to Lear and to Cordelia-
The battle done, and they within our power,
Shall never see his pardon; for my state
Stands on me to defend, not to debate. Exit.

scenes.title: A field between the two camps. Alarum within.

lines: Enter, with Drum and Colours, the Powers of France over the stage, Cordelia with her Father in her hand, and exeunt. Enter Edgar and Gloucester.

blocks.speaker: edgar
lines: Here, father, take the shadow of this tree
For your good host. Pray that the right may thrive.
If ever I return to you again,
I'll bring you comfort.

blocks.speaker: glouchester
lines: Grace go with you, sir!
Exit [Edgar].
Alarum and retreat within. Enter Edgar,

blocks.speaker: edgar
lines: Away, old man! give me thy hand! away!
King Lear hath lost, he and his daughter ta'en.
Give me thy hand! come on!

blocks.speaker: glouchester
lines: No further, sir. A man may rot even here.

blocks.speaker: edgar
lines: What, in ill thoughts again? Men must endure
Their going hence, even as their coming hither;
Ripeness is all. Come on.

blocks.speaker: glouchester
lines: And that's true too.          Exeunt.
Enter, in conquest, with Drum and Colours, Edmund; Lear and Cordelia as prisoners; Soldiers, Captain.

blocks.speaker: edmund
lines: Some officers take them away. Good guard
Until their greater pleasures first be known
That are to censure them.

blocks.speaker: cordelia
lines: We are not the first
Who with best meaning have incurr'd the worst.
For thee, oppressed king, am I cast down;
Myself could else outfrown false Fortune's frown.
Shall we not see these daughters and these sisters?

blocks.speaker: lear
lines: No, no, no, no! Come, let's away to prison.
We two alone will sing like birds i' th' cage.
When thou dost ask me blessing, I'll kneel down
And ask of thee forgiveness. So we'll live,
And pray, and sing, and tell old tales, and laugh
At gilded butterflies, and hear poor rogues
Talk of court news; and we'll talk with them too-
Who loses and who wins; who's in, who's out-
And take upon 's the mystery of things,
As if we were God's spies; and we'll wear out,
In a wall'd prison, packs and sects of great ones
That ebb and flow by th' moon.

blocks.speaker: edmund
lines: Take them away.

blocks.speaker: lear
lines: Upon such sacrifices, my Cordelia,
The gods themselves throw incense. Have I caught thee?
He that parts us shall bring a brand from heaven
And fire us hence like foxes. Wipe thine eyes.
The goodyears shall devour 'em, flesh and fell,
Ere they shall make us weep! We'll see 'em starv'd first.
Come. Exeunt [Lear and Cordelia, guarded].

blocks.speaker: edmund
lines: Come hither, Captain; hark.
Take thou this note [gives a paper]. Go follow them to prison.
One step I have advanc'd thee. If thou dost
As this instructs thee, thou dost make thy way
To noble fortunes. Know thou this, that men
Are as the time is. To be tender-minded
Does not become a sword. Thy great employment
Will not bear question. Either say thou'lt do't,
Or thrive by other means.
